dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PLANE falling two stories per second. This is real... CUT TO BLACKOUT.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Mayday, Mayday, this is Cactus 1549! Lost both engines. Both engines. BLACK WHIPS INTO...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAPTAIN “SULLY” SULLENBERGER, 57, lithe, intense, is behind the stick of this plummeting plane. ALARMS are sounding. CACOPHONY. VERTIGO. Beside Sully, First Officer -- JEFF SKILES, 49, youthful, handsome. Skiles is desperately trying to get the engines started again.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: No re-light. On one or two. CUT TO BLACKOUT.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: The SCREEN QUIVERS and hums. All we hear is... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 2.

dialogues.speaker: AIR TRAFFIC CONTROL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Cactus 1549, you can land on runway one-three, if you want it, it’s yours.

dialogues.speaker: AUTOMATED VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ‘Pull up, pull up. Terrain. Pull up.’ BLACK INCINERATES TO...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIRE. Both engines howling and useless.

dialogues.speaker: AUTOMATED VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ‘Terrain, terrain, pull up, pull up.’

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Departure control, we can make it back. We’re returning to LaGuardia.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: No relight. We got no power. CUT TO BLACKOUT.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: The sound of the ALARMS wail on. The rip of the falling plane through the pitiless air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ALTIMETER pins toward 0. Out the windshield, only -- WATER, 360.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: (into radio) LaGuardia Tower, 1549. Trying to make 1-3.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: We're too low. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 3.

dialogues.speaker: AUTOMATED VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ‘Terrain. Pull up. Pull up.’ CUT TO BLACKOUT.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: The SCREEN RATTLES and SHORTS IN and OUT.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Come on, just a little further, goddamn it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Manhattan skyline appears, nearly filling the plane's windscreen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PASSENGERS scream and panic. The hellish wait for IMPACT.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Lorrie. I love you. CUT TO BLACKOUT.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Silence. Long silence. CRASH. The -- SOUND of the plane smashing into a high-rise apartment building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane... shears the fourth floor in half. The skin- crawling screech of metal on concrete on bone. EXPLOSION, as the engines catch fire and the plane careens down the city street... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 11 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 4.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Taxis, pedestrians, all vanquished by the hurricane of violence. BOOM. The plane -- EXPLODES. And spreads its damage as it burns. The SCREEN FILLS WITH panic and fire and death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MAN IN SILHOUETTE sits up, his breath banging out of him. CLOSE ON MAN’S FACE Sully. Breathing. Haunted.

dialogues.speaker: SMASH CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. EAST RIVER BIKE PATH -— DAWN 11 We are ON the BACK OF Sully’s head, as he runs fast and hard along the East River. Then AROUND TO Sully’s face, his eyes dark with focus and the shadow of the nightmare he is trying to shed. He wears an all-black sweatsuit, and despite the harsh cold, sweat pours down his expressionless face. Not many out so early on a winter’s dawn. Sully has the pathway mostly to himself. And as he runs... he cannot elude the relentless sounds and images of his nightmare. Out of nowhere... SCREECH and HORN of a CAR as Sully just avoids getting clipped by a passing car. Sully just keeps running... west now, back into the teeth of the city. Unable to get enough speed to elude his own thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: SMASH CUT TO
dialogues.text: 12 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 5.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Just the hum of a hotel room as Sully slowly dresses in his white shirt, (no epaulets), and black pants. Every motion he makes is precise, but a beat slow. And it is too quiet in here. So he remotes on the TV. Every channel he checks is focused on the flight 1549 MIRACLE ON THE HUDSON. Shots of the PLANE IN THE WATER, PASSENGERS on the wings and in the emergency rafts. Ecstatic SURVIVORS hugging on the docks. Surviving passenger BARRY LEONARD, 50, handsome and amazed, is shivering with cold and joy while being interviewed by a TV reporter.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (Southern accent) When I looked out the window and saw he was going to land us in the river... I thought... it’s over. What else could I think? Another channel. Another interview. DIANE HIGGINS, 58, lovely and stunned, is in blissful shock.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE HIGGINS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You think you’re going to die, that’s what you think. And then... miraculously... you don’t. Channel change. Back to Barry.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (into camera) ... I guess I could only say thank you... thank you for saving my life. Sully watches the television and it feels like a show more than the news. Is this his life?

dialogues.speaker: DIANE HIGGINS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Thank you, Captain. (choking up) Thank you. Thank... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 12 13 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 6.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He smooths out the lines in his shirt, looks in the mirror. But somehow can’t quite meet his own gaze. As we PUSH DEEP INTO Sully’s eyes, we hear...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES PORTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (pre-lap) «+. you. Yes, thank you, Captain Sullenberger, for joining us today...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sully and Skiles are sitting in a halogen-bright room, with two glasses of water in front of them. Next to them is MIKE CLEARY, their union rep. He’s 50s, black hair, intense bearing. Across the table from them are the 3 NTSB members. ELIZABETH DAVIS, late 40s, gentle face, BEN EDWARDS, 50s, a banker’s demeanor and focus, and CHARLES PORTER, mid- 40s, Marine-tough, who is beginning the session.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES PORTER
dialogues.text: «+. and welcome also to First Officer Skiles. Glad you could make it in this morning.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Not as glad as we are. Slight laughter.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES PORTER
dialogues.text: For the record, we have an Aircraft Systems Team on this investigation, also Aircraft Structures, MRT, Aircraft Performance, ATC, Wildlife Factors, Survival Factors, and Emergency Response. Today, we begin with our Operations and Human Performance investigation, of the crash of U.S. Air Flight 1549.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Water landing.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES PORTER
dialogues.text: Captain? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 7.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: This was not a crash. It was not a ditching. We knew what we were executing. A forced water landing.

dialogues.speaker: BEN EDWARDS
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you attempt to return to LaGuardia?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: There was simply not enough altitude. The river was the only place long enough, wide enough, and smooth enough to even attempt to land the airplane safely.

dialogues.speaker: BEN EDWARDS
dialogues.text: Air Traffic testified that you stated you were returning to LaGuardia. But you didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: As I began the left turn, I realized I couldn’t make it back. It would have ruled out all other options. Returning would have been a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES PORTER
dialogues.text: Let’s get into how you calculated all those parameters.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: There wasn’t time for calculating. I had to rely on my experience of managing the altitude and speed on thousands of flights, over four decades.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES PORTER
dialogues.text: You're saying you...

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Eyeballed it.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES PORTER
dialogues.text: You eyeballed it?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: The best chance those passengers had was on that river. I'd bet my life on it. In fact, I did. And I would do it again. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 8.

dialogues.speaker: BEN EDWARDS
dialogues.text: Aviation engineers are theorizing that you had enough energy to make it back to a runway.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Engineers are not pilots. They’re wrong. And they weren’t there.

dialogues.speaker: BEN EDWARDS
dialogues.text: Regardless, we have to follow up all implications as part of our investigation.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES PORTER
dialogues.text: Our computers will run return scenario algorithms to generate simulations with your exact parameters. The dual engine loss, the altitude. Everything you faced when you made your decision.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: I'd like to oversee those computer simulations.

dialogues.speaker: BEN EDWARDS
dialogues.text: Not possible during an investigation.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES PORTER
dialogues.text: You stated it was a dual engine failure due to multiple bird- strikes.

dialogues.speaker: BEN EDWARDS
dialogues.text: That would be unprecedented.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Everything is unprecedented. Until it happens the first time. The tension escalates. Mike Cleary shoots Sully a look to calm him down. But -- Sully digs in as the questions continue to come in an overlapping blur.

dialogues.speaker: BEN EDWARDS
dialogues.text: How much sleep did you get the night before?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: 8 hours. Enough. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 9.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES PORTER
dialogues.text: Is it possible your blood sugar was low?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: I was rested. Completely aware of my surroundings.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES PORTER
dialogues.text: When was your last drink, Captain Sullenberger?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: A week ago.

dialogues.speaker: BEN EDWARDS
dialogues.text: Drugs?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: No. Never.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES PORTER
dialogues.text: First Officer Skiles?

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Don’t drink. Never have.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES PORTER
dialogues.text: Captain. How about any troubles at home? A beat.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: No more than anyone else. And nothing that affected my work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darkness. It’s only 5 PM, but night presses in through the windows of the car driving Sully and Skiles and Cleary. In the backseat, Sully looks exhausted. Skiles sits in the front seat, fuming.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Why are they looking for something we did wrong, when it all turned out right? It’s bullshit. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 10.

dialogues.speaker: CLEARY
dialogues.text: It didn’t turn out all right for the airline and their insurance company. We should expect some blowback.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Come on, Mike. What are they going to say, that he shouldn’t have saved everybody?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: It’s not personal, the NTSB is doing their job. Once they have all the facts, it’1l calm down.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: They should just pin on the medal and send you back to work. Sully doesn’t answer. Instead, he starts to dial his cell SULLY’S PHONE (V.O.) ‘The voice mailbox of Lorrie Sullenberger is full and cannot receive further messages.’

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: I didn’t call her since this morning. But apparently everyone else did.

dialogues.speaker: THE DRIVER
dialogues.text: A handsome Egyptian man in his early 50s. He takes the silence as a chance to speak.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Not meaning to bother, but I have to say, it is an honor driving you today.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: What has it been this year so far? Bernie Madoff, the two wars without end, many million new people with no work... And that is just the first two weeks of January. (beat) Friday's headline? This is beautiful. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Driver holds up the Jan. 16th DAILY NEWS. Its headline reads... “HERO ON THE HUDSON.” With Sully’s photo inset.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Hey, Mike. How about we add the driver as a character witness? The car stops as it awaits its chance to turn into the hotel entrance. Traffic keeps them at bay for the moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pack of paparazzi is waiting. INT. CAR —- CONTINUOUS ACTION 16 Sully sees the press and looks away. Then he pulls out his cell phone. Trying Lorrie one more time. It rings and rings and rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LORRIE SULLENBERGER, 50, fit, pretty, is in the backyard. She answers her cell.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: Finally.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: The NTSB had us tied up all day.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: I just wanted to hear your voice on the phone. Been hearing everyone else’s. You'd be amazed at how many ‘cousins’ you have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Driver finally makes the turn and stops outside the hotel. Cameras press up against the window, strobing Sully like a night at Studio 54. A BELLMAN opens the back door of the Town Car and the rush of noise is deafening. Sully has to yank it shut again to hear Lorrie. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Doesn't feel like family here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRANE UP FROM the b.g. to reveal their little street is clotted with worldwide media. Two dozen NEWS TRUCKS. PARABOLIC MICS, hordes of PHOTOJOURNALISTS. The doorbell rings, the home phone rings, news trucks honk as they crowd the tiny street.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: Pretty quiet here, too. Sully’s door gets opened again. Mayhem in the streets. Chants of “Sully... Sully... Sully.”

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: The reporters want me to give an update. Inside the mind of Sully. What should I tell them?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Just tell them...

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: I can’t hear you. Call me back without the cheerleaders.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: I was saying to tell...

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: I can’t hear you. Call. Me. Back. Lorrie hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sully gets out of the car with Skiles exiting the other side. And like Michael Jordan and the rest of the Bulls, the press try to swarm Sully, and let Skiles slip through almost imperceptibly. Skiles waves amiably to Sully, happy to avoid the crush. And Sully is left behind, encircled by COPS keeping the tangle of cameras, arms, and microphones fifteen feet back. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The REPORTERS shout their questions.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: How does it feel to be a miracle maker?

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Show us your cape, Super Sully!

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: How did you pull off the impossible? TIME SLOWS. Each FLASHBULB like a blow to a boxer’s head. Sully winces, blinks, and finally closes his eyes. His anonymity is gone. Forever. And maybe more than that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shower burns. The bathroom is so full of steam that visibility is almost gone. The tub is running hot water and so is the sink. Sully has stuffed towels under the door to maximize the steam effect. Finally, amidst the murk, we see Sully sitting on the edge of the tub, with a wet towel over his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see he is taking long, deep breaths. Trying to slow down his heart, which is still beating at double its regular rate. It’s not working.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The water is all stopped now, though steam lingers. Sully wipes the mirror to see his reflection and it comes back diffuse. Unclear in all the heat. And then the -- NOISE. The unmistakable roar of a PLANE plummeting to the ground. Deafening. He feels the sound crashing towards him, louder and louder. And louder. As Sully hurries in to escape the sound, he finds... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: SILENCE. The sound is gone. Only the slow ticking of the bedside clock. And the fast ticking of his own troubled heart. Everything feels unsafe. Even the ground beneath his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SILHOUETTES of several photographers and reporters shadow the front window as -- Lorrie crosses in front, dialing the home phone. She walks downstairs as she waits. After several rings, it’s picked up.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: I’m thinking about running over the press with the car. Self- defense. Think a jury would convict?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sully, in a robe, with a beer in hand, is on the line.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Yes. Okay. Good.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: I’m taking that as permission. The cops will be coming after you.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Whenever you're ready.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: Sully. Are you even listening to me?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Is there a strange buzz on this line? Do you hear a buzz? Maybe we should talk later.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: Honey. I’ve been waiting all day. This is later. Are you okay? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 15.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Of course. Tired. That’s it. (beat) How are the girls?

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: They're... a little overwhelmed. (beat) Sounds like you are, too.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: They'll be all right. It’s a lot. The sound of a photographer’s camera clinking against the kitchen window as the photographer comes too close.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: Yes, it is. Lorrie draws the kitchen curtains, then remotes-on the kitchen TV. PULL BACK to reveal Lorrie has muted it.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: The whole world’s talking about you. My Sully. I still can’t believe it. No answer.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: They need me here longer. For the NTSB investigation. Did I tell you that already?

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: Sully, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Just tired. I apologize if I didn’t tell you.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: You don’t have to apologize. You’re where you need to be.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: I just want you to know. I did the best I could.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: Of course you did. You saved everyone. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 16.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Maybe we can talk tomorrow. The fatigue is... it feels like someone is inside my skin, sitting on my bones.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: Do you want me to come be with you?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Lorrie. But the girls... need you there. (beat) Tell them I love them, okay?

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: I love you. Get some sleep.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Yeah. And maybe when I wake up, it will be January 14th. That would be nice. They hang up. Both standing still. 3,000 miles of distance between them. And somehow, even further apart. DISSOLVE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE COURIC, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (pre-lap) Why Captain Sullenberger made that fateful decision to turn the Hudson River into a runway, only he can answer... but we now know that it was the wrong choice...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sully’s in his sweats. “CBS News” is on, the volume peaked, replaying endless clips of the Miracle on the Hudson. On TV, KATIE COURIC stands by the Hudson River.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE COURIC, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: «+. A choice that endangered the lives of all on board. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 25 26 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 17.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE COURIC, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And while much of the country hails him as a hero, this new information will certainly change everyone's understanding of the so- called ‘Miracle on the Hudson.’ Sometimes fireworks only exist to disguise fraud. From the banks of the Hudson, I’m Katie Couric. CBS News. Sully jerks AWAKE. He’s lying down in the hotel room. But the TV has been OFF the entire time. In fact, it’s UNPLUGGED. He rubs his face, wishing he could get his hands inside his skull to silence his brain. The clock reads 12:41 AM. He picks up his phone several times. Half dials Lorrie. Quits. Finally picks up the hotel phone and dials an extension. Two rings until... INT. JEFF SKILES’ HOTEL ROOM - SAME TIME 26 Skiles is sitting in a chair next to his made bed, drinking a soda, eating a mini-bar Snickers. He grabs the ringing phone.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Jeff. Sorry to call this late.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: It’s okay. No sleep in this room, either. Can you believe they charge five dollars for a Snickers? I could bankrupt the airline in about four bites.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Just wanted to see if... maybe you wanted...

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: .».. to talk? Absolutely. Let’s grab some air...  27 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 18.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wind-whipped streets are empty and the closed storefronts and window displays make the street feel even emptier. The night is mean with cold and Sully and Skiles walk north on 5th Avenue, bundled up. Words don’t come easy.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: You enjoying the shakes, the nightmares, and the rabbit heartbeat?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: A little bit. (beat) The union offered us counseling...

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: What are they going to say? You were in a plane crash. And lived. It may have a minor impact on your day-to-day.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: I just... hate not being able to control this process. I want myself back.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: I’m hoping that six months from now, we’ll just be laughing about how we got to meet David Letterman.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: We're doing ‘Letterman’?

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Right after the NTSB interview. I’m guessing Dave will be funnier.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: It’s all so surreal. I guess I’m just having a little trouble separating reality from... whatever the hell this is.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: This... is two men freezing their asses off. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 27 28 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 19.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They laugh, the steam from their mouths like unspoken thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Sully... don’t worry. You dida great thing and it’s going to be remembered for a very long time.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Funny thing is... I’ve delivered a million passengers, over 40 years in the air... and in the end I’1l be judged on 208 seconds.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Come on. Tomorrow's going to be a good day. Computer SIMS will prove you were right and we can all put our wings back on.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: You're right. You're right. All back to normal. EXTREME CLOSEUP - SULLY’S EYES The street lights reflecting, as we...

dialogues.speaker: MATCH DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: ANOTHER EXTREME CLOSEUP - SULLY’S EYES 28 Lights still reflecting, but these are TV lights. PULL BACK to reveal he is sitting across from...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATIE COURIC and her camera crew.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: ... it was obvious this was a critical situation... losing thrust in both engines, at a low altitude... over one of the most densely populated areas on the planet...

dialogues.speaker: KATIE COURIC
dialogues.text: But choosing to land on the Hudson... there was still a big if... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 28 29 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 20.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: I was sure I could do it.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE COURIC
dialogues.text: You were?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE COURIC
dialogues.text: How do you feel about people calling you a hero?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: I don’t feel like a hero. I was just a man doing his job.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE COURIC
dialogues.text: The right man for the job, at the right time. You’ve been flying for nearly 40 years.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: 42. It has been my life. My whole life. Sully’s eyes spark bright for a moment as we -- ZOOM INTO them and COME BACK OUT THROUGH --

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: Seeing all of Denison, Texas stretched out below him. Sixteen-year-old Sully sits in the front of this tandem two-seater prop plane. In the backseat is L.T. COOK, 50s, clean-shaven and gruff, but aware he’s witnessing the birth of a pilot.

dialogues.speaker: L.T. COOK
dialogues.text: Your aircraft. In the roar of the tiny cockpit, L.T. Cook circles the stick to signal it’s Sully’s plane, then takes his hands off the override controls. Sully circles his stick back in response.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: (amazed) My aircraft. Sully flies. He dips low over the verdant Texas landscape. Low enough for his parents -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 29 30 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 21.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CHESLEY and PAULINE Sullenberger to wave up at him, proudly. He soars back up against the perfect blue and he looks absolutely in control. And free. Looks like he never wants to come down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sully lands the plane on his own. When the wheels touch down, it’s as if Sully’s memorizing the feel. The thrill. He was up there. Now he’s down here. He did it. Him. He and L.T. disembark and stand on the grass strip as the propeller does its final spin.

dialogues.speaker: L.T. COOK
dialogues.text: I‘’1l be busy crop dusting in the Super Cub the rest of the summer. So you can take the plane up, I guess. When you please. Sully doesn’t say anything.

dialogues.speaker: L.T. COOK
dialogues.text: Still six bucks an hour. I’11 consider it lesson time. A pilot never stops acquiring knowledge. You’1l make mistakes, everyone does. Just learn from them.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: L.T. COOK
dialogues.text: And never forget, no matter what’s happening, to fly the airplane.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Absolutely, sir.

dialogues.speaker: L.T. COOK
dialogues.text: One other thing. And this is important.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Yes, sir?

dialogues.speaker: L.T. COOK
dialogues.text: You can go ahead and smile. Sully’s face unleashes a deeply satisfied smile.  31 32 33 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sully flies alone, trying out new maneuvers. Memorizing everything on the panels, constantly testing himself, improving. He banks into the blue, and when he returns to level, we are...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this time his Mother is on board. PAULINE Sullenberger is 41 and attractive. She’s also relaxed, hands calmly on her lap, as if out for a Sunday drive.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Your stomach’s not queasy, Mom?

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Not too noisy for you?

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: No, now let’s enjoy. Just go low and slow. She reaches over and squeezes his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: You realize that if you’d studied piano like this, we’d be on our way to Carnegie Hall now.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: This is my piano, Mom. (pause) And I can still get us to Carnegie Hall. They laugh and she squeezes his hand, beyond proud. PUSH IN CLOSE ON Sully’s joy-filled face, not a drop of sweat despite the Texas heat...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sully’s face, now 57, and moist with sweat. The Katie Couric interview is over. Lights get switched off, camera packed up. Katie’s long gone, and -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 33 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 23.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ALISON, cute, mid-20s, is removing the rest of Sully’s foundation, but he can’t stop sweating.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Sorry about the perspiration.

dialogues.speaker: ALISON
dialogues.text: After what you did, I’d think that Katie couldn’t be too intimidating.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Not Katie. The lights and camera she brought with her.

dialogues.speaker: ALISON
dialogues.text: (beat) All done. Alison gets on tiptoes and kisses Sully’s cheek.

dialogues.speaker: ALISON
dialogues.text: That was from my mom. Her name’s Brenda. She says to say thank you, and she’s single. They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Tell Brenda thanks, but I’ve got a girl at home.

dialogues.speaker: ALISON
dialogues.text: Lucky woman. Alison exits and... Sully is alone. Waiting in this strange hotel room, amidst the silence of not knowing what is going to happen next... he feels like the last man on Earth. He stares out onto the streets of Midtown 30 floors below. Reflected in the window, we see the city before him. And then... A PLANE... plummeting towards the Manhattan skyline. SULLY’S POV As the jet descends relentlessly across the canyon of buildings, hidden by high-rises and then reappearing, like a ghost that won’t perish. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 33 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 24.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Half the left wing severs free as it slams a building, then the plane vanishes again, behind a wall of skyscrapers. BOOM. The plane detonates out of view, fire and debris licking out and around, still visible... the explosion echoing through the streets.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sully. Sully...

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: still gazing out the window. His eyes are vacant, his nightmare still shadowing him. But there is no reflection in the window. And outside, there is no plane in ruins. No fire. Just the city in motion.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sully! Finally, Sully whiplashes back to find -- Mike Cleary, his union rep, standing by the door.

dialogues.speaker: CLEARY
dialogues.text: Sully, where are you? Sully looks out the window one last time. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: CLEARY
dialogues.text: I’m standing here, calling your name... what’s up with you? Sully keeps staring out. Transfixed.

dialogues.speaker: CLEARY
dialogues.text: You need to get focused, because the media request avalanche continues. Larry Rooney volunteered to jump in and ride shotgun with you the rest of the way. Thought you might need a friend. He’ll take you to today’s NTSB meeting. (beat) Sully. Are you hearing me? Sully finally looks at Cleary. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 33 34 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 25.

dialogues.speaker: CLEARY
dialogues.text: Airbus completed their computer simulations as well.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Good. Good. That will help.

dialogues.speaker: CLEARY
dialogues.text: There’s something else. Arnie Gentile called... he got the ACARS data. (beat) The left engine was still operating at idle. Sully feels like he’s been stabbed.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: That’s not possible. I felt it go. It was like being stopped in mid-air.

dialogues.speaker: CLEARY
dialogues.text: Arnie said there was a chance it was sub-idle. That it still could’ve had thrust. Sully doesn’t answer.

dialogues.speaker: CLEARY
dialogues.text: Just thought you should know. Since the NTSB already does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WOLF PACK OF PAPARAZZI at the hotel door, as -- Sully exits the hotel where the Katie Couric interview just took place. His eyes show an unfamiliar reticence, and he scans the crowd for a familiar face. He finds one in -- LARRY ROONEY. 47, stocky, friendly, intense. He wears a U.S. Air uniform, snugly over a slight paunch. Larry waves from beside the car and Sully slowly makes his way through the mayhem. Larry pulls him free of the final strangers, into a vehicle. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 34 35 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 26.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Larry. Nice to finally see a friendly face. The Town Car’s dark windows turn the media throng into a horde of silhouettes.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Might be the last one you see today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tension is high as Sully and Skiles sit across from the investigators. Rooney is by their side for support. And -- Skiles is riled up.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Isn’t it a little early in the year to go fishing?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES PORTER
dialogues.text: Seeking the facts is hardly fishing, Mr. Skiles.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Okay. Then here is the most important fact. There are only two people who know what happened in the cockpit that day, and I’m one of them.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES PORTER
dialogues.text: And we appreciate your perspective...

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Why do you think we’re even here today? It’s because Captain Sullenberger did not head back to LaGuardia. No response. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 27.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Look, I just finished training on the A320, and I can tell you that the only reason the plane operated as well as it did, that the aircraft could land anywhere, is because Captain Sullenberger turned on the Auxiliary Power Unit.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH DAVIS
dialogues.text: He was simply following the QRH...

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: No. He wasn’t following the proper procedure at all. And I know, because I had the QRH in my hands. The board leans forward. Interested.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: He switched on the APU immediately after engine roll back. According to Airbus, that’s the fifteenth thing on the list to do. Fifteenth. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: If he’d followed the damn rules, we'd all be dead. (heating up) Maybe that’s the part you don’t like. You’re not used to having answers to your guesses.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: (smoothing) Look, what Jeff is saying is that I know the A320. What it does and doesn’t do. I’ve read countless CVR transcripts of deceased pilots and I have significant accident investigation experience.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES PORTER
dialogues.text: There is no question that you are an experienced, dedicated, talented professional. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 28.

dialogues.speaker: BEN EDWARDS
dialogues.text: But all the flights you piloted before January 15th and every crash you investigated are not the purview of this investigation. Only U.S. Airways 1549 matters today. The room takes a breath.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH DAVIS
dialogues.text: Your union has been advised... ACARS data relayed that the left engine continued to turn throughout the flight.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Then the data would be wrong.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH DAVIS
dialogues.text: The evidence shows the left engine was at idle or sub-idle immediately following the bird strike.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: (punched) Show me the left engine and it’1l be dead geese and no power.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH DAVIS
dialogues.text: The left engine was lost in the crash, due to the extensive damage on touchdown, but we’1ll circle back to that. Let’s assume it was, aS you say, a dual engine loss due to bird strike...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES PORTER
dialogues.text: Your weight was 151,510 lbs. Wind and temperature, N-NW, 21 degrees. Speed and altitude, 200 knots at 2,818 feet. Agreed?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: That’s correct.

dialogues.speaker: BEN EDWARDS
dialogues.text: We were able to run all the algorithms concurrently. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 29.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES PORTER
dialogues.text: And the resulting computer simulations of U.S. Airways Flight 1549 showed that the aviation engineers... were correct.

dialogues.speaker: BEN EDWARDS
dialogues.text: There was enough altitude and speed after the bird strike, for a successful return to LaGuardia.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: (dubious) Successful?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES PORTER
dialogues.text: The plane landed at LaGuardia. Intact. Undamaged.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: You got that from one computer simulation?

dialogues.speaker: BEN EDWARDS
dialogues.text: No. From twenty.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES PORTER
dialogues.text: Including attempts for Teterboro runway 19, and LaGuardia, runways 22 and 13. Every computer simulation, with the exact flight parameters, demonstrated that a return was possible. And not just possible. Probable. The room goes ghost quiet.

dialogues.speaker: BEN EDWARDS
dialogues.text: Does anyone need to hear further computer evidence? Silence.

dialogues.speaker: BEN EDWARDS
dialogues.text: Captain Sullenberger, First Officer Skiles?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: (shaken) Not at this time.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: No. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 30.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: I would like to go over all the parameters used...

dialogues.speaker: BEN EDWARDS
dialogues.text: We’ll make them available to the union.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY ROONEY
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH DAVIS
dialogues.text: And once the investigation is complete, we’ll be able to share the actual computer simulations. For now, they remain confidential. We can’t afford a leak to the press. (beat) There’s been far too much talk in the press already. NTSB stands. The room is somber.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES PORTER
dialogues.text: When the complete Cockpit Voice Recording is compiled, with ATC, and all on-board transcripts combined, we will call you back. The NTSB exits. So does Larry Rooney, who follows them out with hushed questions. Only Sully and Skiles remain. Sully looks stunned.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: They're playing Pac-Man, you were flying a plane full of human beings.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Somehow. Not the way I remember it. It just doesn’t seem right.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Because it’s not right. Sully, you did everything you could. And it was more than enough. Ask the passengers. Ask your wife and kids. Ask mine. The two men stare straight ahead, dumbfounded by the turn of events. PUSH IN CLOSER. CLOSER...

dialogues.speaker: MATCH DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: 36 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 31. INT. HOTEL ROOM - EXTREME CLOSEUP - SULLY AND SKILES’ 36

dialogues.speaker: ... PIXILATED...
dialogues.text: Because we are watching them on TV. Their expressions are now strained smiles, as they weather lighthearted questions from -- DAVID LETTERMAN.

dialogues.speaker: LETTERMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The first thing, the only thing the Captain said over the radio... PULL BACK FROM THE CLOSEUP to reveal that Sully and Skiles are both in full uniform and are standing behind flight attendants. DONNA DENT, 51, short hair, lovely smile... SHEILA DAIL, a very pretty and young 57... and DOREEN WELSH, 50, strong, confident... on the set of “David Letterman”.

dialogues.speaker: LETTERMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: «+. was ‘Brace for impact’?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ‘Brace for impact.’ Yes. The flight attendants all have the wonder of survival on their faces. And -- Skiles seems utterly at ease under the lights. Sully looks hemmed in. The one person at the dance who is hearing a different music. PULL BACK ALL THE WAY to reveal -- Sully has been watching his and the crews’ performance on Letterman, taped earlier that night, on his hotel room television. He holds his cell phone to his ear as it rings out.

dialogues.speaker: LETTERMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (on TV) ‘Brace for impact.’ Ever hear that before, coming out of a cockpit?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (on TV) No, not ever. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 36 37 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 32.

dialogues.speaker: LETTERMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (on TV) Ever hear that in any other aspect of your lives? The audience and the crew laugh, but Sully’s no longer listening, he’s connected on the phone with...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lorrie. She’s on the cordless, walking through their house.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: I’m sure you were fine.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Nervous as hell. Jeff was relaxed and funny. He should be getting all the interview requests.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: How long before we get you back?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: The girls miss you. I miss you. Lorrie peeks out the curtain. All the media trucks remain.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: Are they paying you to do all this media stuff, at least?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: It’s news, Lorrie. No payment necessary.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: Wish the bank felt the same way. Lorrie reaches their bedroom, only her side of the bed slept in. She takes an open envelope off the nightstand. It’s a bank statement.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: What do you mean? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 33.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: It's just... we got another notice about the space in Butte County.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: We’ll find a tenant. It takes time.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: You've been saying that for nine months, Sully, and it’s still vacant.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: The economy... has to take a turn...

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: If we lose that space, it feels like the next domino to fall... is the house.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: We’re not going to lose the house. Lorrie, what are you...?

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Feeling a little anxious and alone at the moment. Not a lot of sleep...

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: I know. Not much sleep here, either.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: Just tell me you’1l be back in the air soon.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Not before the NTSB finishes the investigation.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: We need you flying.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Well, they’re in no rush. It’s their job to scrutinize every thought I had, every syllable I uttered, every choice I made.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: Of course you'll be back flying. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 34.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Lor. If it goes badly, my career as a safety expert will end as a website and a business card.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: I’m more worried about your career as a pilot. A pause. Then...

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: What if I did blow it?

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: Wait.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: If I got this wrong, so close to the end of my career... if I endangered those passengers’ lives...

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: Sully. Watch the news. You’re a hero. And everybody’s going to have to get used to it. Including the NTSB.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: The NTSB doesn’t like heroes. They like to find and assign responsibility.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: (worried) What do you mean ‘responsibility?’

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Worst case scenario, the NTSB lists me as the probable cause... immediate retirement. No pension... a life’s work... gone.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: I don’t understand what you’re saying... this could all fall on us?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: If it’s my fault, it should.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: What fault? You won. They can’t take that away from you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 35.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Since I was 16 with L.T., the one thing I’ve focused on was excellence. Attention to every last detail. And now they’re etching my epitaph as, ‘He crashed a 60 million-dollar airplane in the river.’ Goddammit. I feel like I’m in a vice, but I’m the one who can’t stop tightening it.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: You’re scaring me. Sully, what’s going on? Long silence.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: The left engine... it might have still been idling. And the Airbus computer simulations... they say I could have made it back. Lorrie’s worry is an unspoken sound.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: It doesn’t make any sense. Doesn't jibe with what it felt like in the cockpit, but... dammit.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: Why did you do it? Sully. Land in the water? Sully hears the ROAR OF APPLAUSE and laughter from the “LETTERMAN” SHOW, in direct contrast to how far away his wife and his old life feel.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: Wasn’t that the most dangerous thing you could have done?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: I did it because... I knew... I thought... it was the only chance for survival. Lorrie hears the uncharacteristic doubt in her husband’s voice. She looks at the bank notice and other unopened bills. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 37 38 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue)

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: Now all we have to do is survive surviving. Long silence. Two people breathing, unable to find the words.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: Come home.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: I can’t.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Ever have the feeling... that you don’t want to be anywhere at all?

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: Thanks, Sully.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: It’s not you, Lorrie. I need you. And the girls. I just, I’m not myself. If I did fly back, it wouldn’t be me you’re getting.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: What happened up there, Sully?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: I thought I knew. 36.

dialogues.speaker: SMASH CUT TO
dialogues.text: FLASHBACK - INT. LaGUARDIA AIRPORT - DAY (JAN. Sully rolls airport and stops for a
an Indian woman.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: The tuna/basil, Gursimran? Or the ham and cheddar.

dialogues.speaker: GURSIMRAN
dialogues.text: Tuna/basil, Mr. Sully. Very fresh. (beat) Be careful up there, too cold today. Too much cold.
his carry-on luggage through the crowded he’s got a friendly word for everyone. He sandwich from his regular vendor, GURSIMRAN, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 37.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: When are you going to come fly with me?

dialogues.speaker: GURSIMRAN
dialogues.text: When U.S. AIR starts flights to Hyderabad.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: (laughs ) Let me talk to the chairman. See what I can do. Sully pays and rolls on, but -- CAMERA LINGERS BEHIND to find -- DIANE HIGGINS, 58, attractive and bright-eyed, pushing her mother, LUCILLE PALMER, 85, in an airport wheelchair. Lucille has an elegant sweep of light gray hair, a gorgeous, brand new, green, velour pantsuit. Anda mischievous smile and spirit.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Just a little something.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE HIGGINS
dialogues.text: The suitcase is already overstuffed with gifts for Will.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Always fun to get something from the airport. Feels like you traveled, too.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE HIGGINS
dialogues.text: Mom. He’s turning one. Don’t think he’1ll be discerning what gift came from where.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: But I will. (beat) Maybe a snow globe. Something he’1l remember. Something New York.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE HIGGINS
dialogues.text: (teasing) Were you this generous when we were kids?

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Okay, sweetheart. I/’11l get youa snow globe, too. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 38 39 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 38.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Mother and daughter laugh and move toward the Lady Liberty snow globes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sully is settling in alongside his First Officer, Jeff Skiles, and running his pre-flight routine to the letter.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: ECAM (ee’kam).

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Checked.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Set.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Altimeters verify three-zero-two- three.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Three-zero-two-three.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Start checklist complete. (pause) Really think they’1l release us?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Just checked the latest reports... we’re clear all the way to Charlotte.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Then steaks at Del Frisco’s. On me.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Never been. I hear good things.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: The rib-eye will break your heart.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: I’m more of a porterhouse man.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: The porterhouse will stop your heart.  40 41 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three MEN in a hurry, racing toward a gate. ROB KOLODJAY, 60, handsome and rumpled in equal measure, tries to keep pace with the hurrying -- JEFF KOLODJAY, his son. Jeff is 31 and young De Niro good-looking. Keeping stride with Jeff is -- JIMMY STEFANIK, 27, a cousin, with close-cropped hair and a worried face.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Jeff, we're not going to make it.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Been waiting a year for this trip, Dad. I am not missing this flight. (beat) We'll meet you at the gate. Jeff and Jimmy take off into a full run. Rob slows, catches his breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff and Jimmy slalom through a final clutch of people and reach the gate for Flight 1549. No line. Just an extremely pretty gate attendant, name tag “EMILY.” She is 38 and focused on her paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Spirit sent us. We got canceled and they said we were rerouted. That you guys had seats. Emily doesn’t look up.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Flight is closed.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Wait. Wait. See the old guy, just limping up? That’s my dad. He needs to be on this flight. It’s an emergency.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: (dubious) What kind of emergency? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 40.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: A golf emergency. Emily cannot suppress a grin.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I.D.s, please. How many people are traveling?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Three. And thank you...

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Nothing together.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Hell. I’11 fly on the wing. Rob finally reaches the gate, a little winded.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Canceled, right? Ought to be.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Here we go. (extending boarding passes) 22A, 6A, and 6C.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: I Googled you last night. Read all about your company on your website. Impressive.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Man, I thought I was a good bullshitter, but you could go pro.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: I’m only teasing. But the site does make your air safety consulting business sound like you've got about 100 employees and headquarters in three states. But then, when I dug deeper, I realized... it’s only you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 42 43 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 41.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Go easy, I’m just getting it going. (beat) Not usually accused of being a bullshitter.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Don’t take it wrong. Actually a compliment. Off that website... I'd hire you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheila is preparing to close the main cabin door when -- Rob, Jeff, and Jimmy appear, just slip on. They walk down the aisle, squeezing by people jamming OVERSIZED BAGS into the overhead bins. Jeff starts heading further down the aisle.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Where you headed? Jeff, we're here in 6.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: That’s all Jimmy. I was up ‘til three. I need to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: You can sleep here.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Not with you verbally walking the course the whole flight. ‘Think I’ll go... with the nine iron on the 7th.’ No. No. Good night... As Jeff walks deeper into the cabin, he passes PASSENGER WITH BABY, 33, a lovely mother sitting alone with her eight-month-old, DAMIAN. The baby rifles through the seat-back magazines and safety instructions like he’s looking for treasure. Sitting at the window by the woman is JIM WHITAKER, gentle, 46, and busy scooping up what Damian is tossing.

dialogues.speaker: PASSENGER WITH BABY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. He likes to throw everything. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JIM WHITAKER
dialogues.text: (smiling) Perfect. I like to catch everything. Jeff walks deeper into the plane, past a couple speaking in Russian... Past a man speedily texting before the doors get cross- checked. Past a WOMAN wrestling with a too-big bag in a too-small overhead. Jeff delivers the final shove and the bag jams into place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donna begins the SAFETY INSTRUCTIONS over the PA while -- Sheila demonstrates in the front of the cabin and Doreen demonstrates at the back. All three work with practiced and professional enthusiasm. Almost -- NO ONE is paying attention.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: «+. please review the safety instruction card in the seat-back pocket in front of you... 80% of the passengers are mentally elsewhere. Reading magazines, catching a snooze.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: «+. your seat cushion serves as a flotation device...

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: LaGuardia Ramp, Cactus 1549, ready for pushback at gate 21.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Cactus 1549, gate 21, cleared to push, spot 28, ground for taxi.  SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The flight attendants do final checks, buckle in, and then they feel the plane -- Halt on the tarmac. Donna checks her watch as Sheila joins her in the galley.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: Just once, I’d like to get out of LaGuardia on time.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Sheila, you know there’s only one way to depart LaGuardia on time.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Fly out of JFK. They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Takeoff min. fuel quantity, verify. 19,000 pounds required, we got 21.8 onboard.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: 19,000 pounds required, 21.8 onboard.

dialogues.speaker: TOWER RADIO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Cactus 1549, runway four, clear for takeoff.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Cactus 1549, cleared for takeoff. Skiles picks up speed as they begin down the runway.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: TOGA set. They build acceleration... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 44,

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Checked.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: V one, rotate. They liftoff and start to climb.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Positive rate.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Gear up, please.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Gear up. Sully unclips his shoulder harness, as is his ritual, and slips out of it for comfort during the flight. It could not be more beautiful. Up above the weather, the sky is stunning. Sunlight reflects off the Hudson like a million spilled diamonds. This is the glory of flying.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: What a view of the Hudson. (beat) I will never get over how beautiful it is up here.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Life’s easier in the air.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Yes. It. Is. Skiles guides the plane higher. The splendor of the New York skyline appears off in the distance. A moment of quiet wonder. Until a sudden black curtain of GEESE covers the windshield and darkens their view up ahead.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Birds!

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Oh, shit!  48 49 50 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geese from the flock get SUCKED INTO each engine. Blood. Shredded bone and metal. Both engines cough and bang to a -- STOP. FIRE rages in the right engine well. Useless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The alarm begins to chime. Banging and ringing every 5.7 seconds. Sully is Wyatt Earp CALM amidst the madness of the alarms.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: We got one roll... both of ‘em rolling back. Ignition start. (beat) I’m starting the APU. He turns on the AUXILIARY POWER UNIT. The engines are toast, but the plane’s flight controls can now continue to work. He’s bought them a sliver of time.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: My aircraft. Sully takes over flying the plane, despite feeling the narrowing of his VISION and the spiking of his PULSE. He forces himself to concentrate.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Your aircraft.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Get the QRH. Loss of thrust on both engines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is filled with CONTROLLERS and SUPERVISORS behind their consoles. Another day of focus and details. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 50 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 46.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: (into radio) Mayday, Mayday, Mayday. This is Cactus 1549. Hit birds. 34-year-old, stocky, handsome, thick New York accent. Patrick, the ACT, hasn’t heart Sully’s Mayday. He has keyed his microphone and is talking to another departing aircraft in his charge, oblivious to the danger.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (relaxed) Maintain one-five thousand, Delta. Patrick releases his mic, sips his coffee in time to finally hear.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: We've lost thrust on both engines. We’re turning back towards LaGuardia. Patrick jumps on the emergency immediately.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Okay, Cactus 1549, turn left heading two-two-zero. (beat) Which engine did you lose?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Both. Both engines. Patrick goes off radio and shouts to his SUPERVISOR, 54, thin, vigilant, two consoles away.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Supe, I have an emergency. Supervisor hustles to Patrick’s console. Plugs his headset into the console above Patrick's.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: What’s the report?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Both engines.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: What? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Both engines gone. No thrust.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: (receiving info over headset) LaGuardia says bring him around to one-three.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (into radio) Cactus 1549, if we can get it for you, do you want to try runway one- three?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALARMS are chattering at Sully. Ringing. Warning. The plane is dropping. Two stories per second. But he remains steadfast.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: (realizing) Unable. We may end up in the Hudson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick works the touch screen to carve out a path to Teterboro. Supervisor is on the phone calling for rescue support from the Coast Guard, police helicopters, any and everyone. Patrick demands the rest of the controllers’ attention.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I’ve got an A320 diving for the river. Patrick turns to his colleague, Al, at the next console.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Al, stack all the inbounds to LaGuardia.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What about New Jersey? Maybe Teterboro?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (into radio) Teterboro Tower, I need a runway. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cactus 1549 needs to go to the airport right now. Newark Tower, what have you got?

dialogues.speaker: NEWARK TOWER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You have runway 2-9, cleared and ready. Need emergency...?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Yes. Patrick looks back at the radar screen just as -- The L.A. (low altitude) light flashes on-screen and the data block spells out the rapid descent. The MSAW plays out the beep-beep-beep alarm of a plane in altitude danger. On the screen, the plane drops as if off a cliff.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Shit. (into radio) Cactus 1549, turn right two-eight- zero. You can land runway one, Teterboro and I also got you Newark, off your two o’clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PUSH INTO Sully’s eyes. The reflection of the sun off the river close enough to REFLECT in his calm eyes... as we see him make the DECISION.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: We can’t do it. We’re gonna be in the Hudson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1549 VANISHES from the radar screen.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Cactus 1549 radar contact lost. You also got Newark off your two o'clock in about seven miles. Silence. Patrick’s heart is in his throat.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (off radio) Don’t go in the river. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into radio) 1549? You... still on? No response. Patrick works the touchscreen, the radar screen, anything to bring the plane back.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (into radio) Cactus 1549, if you can... you got * runway two-nine available at * Newark it’1l be two o’clock and * seven miles. * Patrick’s whole being wills contact. None comes.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (off radio) Come on. Please, God. * Supervisor looks at Patrick’s blank screen. Hangs up his phone line.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: Patrick. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: He’s inbound to Newark, I know it. He just went off the box to focus.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: Patty.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: He’1l come back up. He’s on his way to Teterboro. We need other eyes and ears. (into radio) Attention, all aircraft in * vicinity of the GW, we have an * A320 on emergency descent... *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SIGHTSEEING HELICOPTER is darting its way above the city skyline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MALE PILOT, 40, scattered whiskers, operates the copter, with two TOURISTS, a young FRENCH COUPLE on a honeymoon, in back. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 56 57 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 50.

dialogues.speaker: MALE PILOT
dialogues.text: When we come around this bend, we'll be looking at the U.S.S. Intrepid. One of New York's... Pilot pauses as over the radio he hears...

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Cactus 1549 is low level, above the Hudson. Just as 1549 comes INTO VIEW... two hundred feet below them. Male Pilot increases altitude to create space and keys the radio.

dialogues.speaker: MALE PILOT
dialogues.text: This is Four-Six-One Sierra Alpha. I have him.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Okay, okay.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I’ve got a chopper with visual. I’m staying on this. Supervisor backs off a few feet.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: He’s out there, he’s headed to Newark. Seven miles, only seven miles. Patrick changes transmitters to the “REMOTE TRANSMITTER.”

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (into radio) Cactus 1549, do you read? Silence. Patrick hits another button.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: He’s on emergency. That’s it. Call Newark, see if they see him. Supervisor knows what’s waiting, but he calls Newark anyway. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 57 58 59 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue)

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (into radio) Cactus 1549, this is departure control on guard, do you read?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The heli chases the descending plane. Only the inevitable awaits.

dialogues.speaker: MALE PILOT
dialogues.text: Shit. He’s going down.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: .».. Cactus 1549, do you read me?

dialogues.speaker: MALE PILOT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (into radio) He’s going down. (beat) He’s gonna hit the water. Patrick goes sheet white. Supervisor puts his hand on Patrick’s shoulder. Patrick keeps staring at the blank radar screens in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: (to another controller) Take Patrick’s seat. A CONTROLLER takes Patrick’s spot and plugs in to the console, replacing him.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: Testers will come down. Urine sample, breathalyzer. Standard.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: His voice was so calm. When he said the Hudson, I didn’t believe it. This isn’t happening. (beat) People don’t survive water landings, Henry. Sudden tears. He can’t wipe them away. 51. 57

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: his phone * (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: All those people. God help them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The river beckons from outside the window. Time is up. The cockpit alarms RINGING, RINGING, RINGING. Sully looks out the window. Too late to go back. Only the river ahead. Reaches for the radio to the cabin.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: (into PA) This is the Captain. (pause) Brace for impact. Sully thinks about saying more to the cabin. Doesn't. Hand steady, he sets the PA mic down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stewardesses buckle in, while shouting instructions. They chant it out in unison...

dialogues.speaker: STEWARDESSES
dialogues.text: (in unison) Brace! Brace! Brace! Heads down! Stay down! Brace! Brace! Brace! But the passengers can’t help but look out the windows. In row 17, Diane holds Lucille’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE HIGGINS
dialogues.text: (crying) I love you, Mom. I love you, I love you.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: To the moon and the stars and...

dialogues.speaker: DIANE HIGGINS
dialogues.text: (trembling) .»-. and all the way back. In row 6, Jimmy grabs Rob’s arm. They hold fast.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: We’re not gonna make it, Uncle Robbie. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: In row 1, Barry Leonard is braced with only the bulkhead to smack into. He is praying. We can’t hear the words, but his face looks totally peaceful. As if he has already surrendered. In row 19, Passenger With Baby is trembling. Without a seat belt for her lap child, she doesn’t know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: JIM WHITAKER
dialogues.text: Let me hold him. And Passenger With Baby trusts Jim with her child. Jim holds onto Damian with strength and tenderness. In row 12, a MAN writes “Mom, Jane - I love you.” on his business card, with a shaky hand. Then he plants the card deep into his pocket, so that when he does not survive, the note just might. In row 22, Jeff watches the water speeding up toward the plane. Then he shuts the blind. Unable to watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chimes. Alarms. Automated warnings. Sully begins the flare for landing. Sidestick back, back, full aft.

dialogues.speaker: WARNING SYSTEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ‘Pull up, pull up, pull up, pull up.’ Sully gives the airplane everything he’s got. But it won’t give him any more.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: We’re gonna brace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sully is spent from the telling. The hotel clock has rolled to 12:57 AM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lorrie holds the phone so tight, she’s white-knuckled. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: I have to go.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Sully. I love you.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: I have to go. Sully hangs up. His hands, so steady in flight, now shaking a little. And he and Lorrie are left on opposite sides of the divide between before Flight 1549. And after.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blinding images include the NEWS SCROLL announcing the Miracle on the Hudson, on a seemingly endless loop. Then, through the tourist crowd, jogging, fast, comes Sully. It’s another frigid winter night, but Sully is in his black sweatsuit and he is on the move. And yet, running cannot turn off the images that rush at him from inside his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sully runs deeper into Times Square and the SCROLL changes to an endless loop of “Flight 1549 CRASH. Pilot needlessly risks lives of all on board.” “Pilot error. Pilot error.” Sully runs harder and harder, trying to run out of his skin. But every step brings another flash. He heads west on 45th Street, away from the glare and cacophony. At Tenth Avenue... he turns, right, directly into a huge congregation of -- PIGEONS... The noise of their panicky flight, the gray black of their wings, shoot Sully back to the -- GEESE curtaining the jet’s windshield... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He stops. The last pigeons vanishing into the darkness. Every corner is just another edge of his mental prison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sully is now running across 12th Avenue and headed for the Hudson. He’s at a full clip, as if chased. The CAMERA GETS so TIGHT ON his face, the entire world is his breathing, his breath like smoke signals in the frigid night. He hears the voices of LORRIE, her slip of doubt... of SKILES, backing him up all the way... of his MOTHER, her pride clear... of MIKE CLEARY, about the left engine still being alive... of L.T. COOK, saying details are the difference between life and death... never stop flying the plane... An endless stream of VOICES, all overlapping into a cacophonous attack. Inescapable. Even his running is a trap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the railing to the river, Sully stammers to a stop. His heart bangs. Lungs and legs burn. Finally his mind goes -- SILENT. He looks out at the inky river. As if the runway he chose could tell him why he chose it. But it offers nothing. He turns to see the -- U.S.S. INTREPID. The deck of the aircraft carrier/museum is dotted with aircraft. A Concorde SST. A Lockheed A-12. An F/A-18. All visible from the river’s edge. His eyes focus on the FIGHTER PLANE. He can almost feel himself behind the stick... as we...

dialogues.speaker: SMASH CUT TO
dialogues.text: 68 69 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: F-4 in flight. Low altitude, high-speed and the -- 26-YEAR-OLD SULLY in charge of the military exercise. The -- SOUND is a feeling down to your bones. Flying barely 100 feet off the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sully is flying, his face a mix of concentration and ecstasy. He was born for this. He is gifted, and fearless. His GIB (guy in back), ANDREW CARRIGAN, 25, takes Sully’s cues and provides Sully with the assistance he needs. They are a synchronized team.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: How you feeling today, Andrew?

dialogues.speaker: GIB
dialogues.text: Rough n’ ready, sir.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Good. Because I feel like flying all day. (into radio) Ready to zoom and boom. Sully circles toward the bombing target when suddenly, his F-4 -- KICKS LEFT. On its own. Inches from a disaster. Only Sully’s deft touch keeping him from trap-dooring into the earth.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Goddammit.

dialogues.speaker: GIB
dialogues.text: What the hell was that?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Sully is pulling on the stick, like riding a bucking bronco. His GIB can only watch and hope. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 69 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 57.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sully decides the only way out is up and he -- PINHOLES the F-4 straight for the skies, pulling maximum Gs. Sully disarms all the bomb switches, runs every check.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Mayday, Mayday, Mayday. This is Tasty One One, flight control malfunction. At 15,000 feet, Sully finally evens out. But the stick is jelly and the plane tugs this way and that.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: (into radio) Las Vegas Approach, Tasty One One with an emergency, flight control malfunction. Need a straight-in approach.

dialogues.speaker: AIR TRAFFIC CONTROL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Okay, Tasty One One, cleared for a visual approach to runway 2-1 right. Keep your turn to final within five miles. Sully begins to descend. But the aircraft is SHAKING like it wants to tear apart. Sully drops to 14 thousand. Thirteen. At twelve a -- GUST OF WIND knocks the right wing down hard, and the plane dips precariously. Sully maintains enough control to get the plane back to level. Despite the high speed descent in an out of control military fighter... Sully looks like he’s having an afternoon by the pool. High-speed approach. Rapid descent. His GIB filled with fear... and -- Sully scorches the landing, clean and mean, the -- DRAG CHUTE deploys and the fighter shreds the clear air as it finally comes to a halt. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: (wry smile) Ready to go back up again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sully’s memory severs. The F-4 on the ship is a museum piece, never to be flown again. As he stands in the black-ice air, he realizes the chances are real that he, too... may never fly again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The neon sign on 11th Avenue highlights Sully ducking inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sully enters to a quiet, nearly anonymous bar. He sits on a bar stool, his face still flushed. BARTENDER, 49 and bearded, slides him a napkin.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Hey. You look like that guy... Sully bows his head a bit.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: «+. the plane with the... Sully.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: I get that a lot.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: All right. Sully! Nice to meet you, sir. That was good, what you did. That was unreal. Sully doesn’t answer. No matter where he goes, he can’t escape his fame.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Check it out, I invented a drink after you. Ask Johnny. Johnny, did I not, right then and there? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 72 73 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 59.

dialogues.speaker: DRUNK CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: Yeah. You did. Fact, I'll take one.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: You’re gonna love ‘The Sully,’ Sully. Ready? Grey Goose. Splash of water. Sully manages a laugh, a small release after trying to restrain so much.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Can't believe you're sitting in my bar. Bartender makes Sully “his” drink.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: To January 15th, the best day of the year. Bartender lifts his own “Sully” to toast. They all drink. Drunk Customer points to the TV mounted on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: DRUNK CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: Hey, look, Pete. Sully’s here, and there. On the wall-mounted TV another report on Flight 1549. It has Sully’s image on the screen, with footage of the plane in the Hudson behind it. Inescapable.

dialogues.speaker: DRUNK CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: He’s everywhere. The TV image goes to a shot of the Hudson and we -- PUSH IN ALL THE WAY UNTIL we -- COME OUT the other side...

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: The Thomas Jefferson ferry is chugging towards its Manhattan port, passengers in every seat.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR GAGGERO
dialogues.text: All NYC confidence and focus is at the helm. He steers the ferry towards its destination. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A DECKHAND, HECTOR RABANES, approaches.

dialogues.speaker: GAGGERO
dialogues.text: Little ice on the city side, and dispatch said the chop’s coming up, so I’m gonna run her real slow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An NYPD air/sea rescue helicopter sits outside the hangar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scuba cop MIKE DELANEY, 32, brown hair, easy manner, is hanging with his partner, ROBERT RODRIGUEZ, 35. The rest of the scuba cops are scattered throughout the break room.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
