dialogues.text: I cannot believe you have the sack to say that. That’s literally like giving the city the finger.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUEZ
dialogues.text: I‘ll say it again, Dennis Eckersley is without question the greatest relief pitcher in the history of baseball.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: You’re blinded by the leg kick. That what it is. Or the moustache.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGUEZ
dialogues.text: You're just jealous he was never a Yankee. They get interrupted by an impossibly loud ALARM... then they scramble back to the helicopter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afternoon traffic crawls and drivers hear the JET ROAR. They crane their necks to see the plane passing directly overhead. It just barely -- CLEARS the bridge.  77 78 79 80 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 61.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One ELDERLY MAN, in his 80s, uses his cane to get to the window. Compassion and hope and fear crowd his heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a city tuned to the fear of planes crashing... countless windows begin to fill with APARTMENT DWELLERS... magneted by the -- SIGHT of Flight 1549 so close to the riverfront. They fishbowl to the glass in building after building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gaggero and the Thomas Jefferson are 50 yards from the dock when he hears an enormous NOISE overhead. All look up. A plane plummeting toward the Hudson.

dialogues.speaker: GAGGERO
dialogues.text: .-. all hands on deck, this is a Mayday! He throws the ferry into full impulse and hurtles forward.

dialogues.speaker: GAGGERO
dialogues.text: This is Victor Gaggero of the Thomas Jefferson. We have a... plane... EXTREME CLOSEUP - GAGGERO’S EYES as they go wide with astonishment. The REFLECTION and the sound of impact tells the story just as the plane hits the Hudson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane hits the water. The passengers react as the plane jerks to a halt. A passenger in the last row dares to open the window blind. Water is already halfway up. Fish in a fishbowl. Surreal. People begin to vacate their seats.  81 82 83 84 85 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 62.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sully bangs OPEN the cockpit door, looks out at the stunned passengers.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Evacuate! Barry Leonard is first by the emergency door as it opens. He looks out onto the freezing river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The life raft has not deployed. Barry is the only one who can see its useless shape, adhered to the plane.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Jump. Jump! Barry takes off his shoes. And obeys. He jumps directly into the frigid water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barry sinks several feet below the surface. Fora moment, it seems this will be his ending place. And then he -- Rises. At the surface, in shock... he begins to swim. But AWAY from the plane... with half a mile between him and the coast. Madness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Icy river water FLOODS into the plane through a gaping hole in the floor. Doreen has BLOOD POURING from a leg wound, but she’s still shouting instructions to passengers.

dialogues.speaker: DOREEN
dialogues.text: The aft exits are unusable! Everyone forward to the overwing exits. Don life vests, now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff is soaked and shivering, water to his knees already.  86 87 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 63.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In row 6, Rob is screaming towards the back of the plane.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Jeff! Jeffrey! The chaos blocks any visual contact. Jimmy dons a life vest and grabs one for his distraught uncle.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Put this on. Uncle Robbie.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Can you see Jeff?! We have to get him. Rob pushes into the aisle, tries to make it back towards Jeff. But the rush of people coming at him make passage impossible. Too many bodies, and Rob winds up pushed back into row 6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In row 17, Diane is unbuckling Lucille’s seat belt. Lucille tries to stop her.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Diane. You have to go.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE HIGGINS
dialogues.text: I’m not leaving...

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: Please go. I'’11 only trap you here.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE HIGGINS
dialogues.text: Mom. I won’t leave you.

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: You have to. Their connection goes deeper than ten thousand words. Diane takes her mother’s face in her hands. After a long moment...

dialogues.speaker: DIANE HIGGINS
dialogues.text: (to the plane) Help! My mother needs help!  88 89 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 64.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY AND SKILES 88
dialogues.text: as they march through the morass of confused passengers.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Come forward! Grab life vests! Sully and Skiles rip free the left behind LIFE VESTS, hand them out as they walk the cabin.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Going to be bitter out there. Sully and Skiles hand out blankets and coats to every departing passenger.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Everyone take a blanket. Pass them along! The freezing water rises. It’s at their knees. Now at their waists. Relentless. The heavy plane is inhaling water and -- SINKING. And still, some passengers are popping open the overhead bins, trying to take their luggage with them. Skiles slams an overhead shut.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Evacuate. Now.

dialogues.speaker: ACTION
dialogues.text: REVEALS the crippled, drowning plane, lonely in the river. Then at the EDGES OF THE FRAME, a cavalcade of -- FERRY BOATS and first responders begin to close the gap.

dialogues.speaker: THE WINGS
dialogues.text: slowly taking on SURVIVORS, hanging on for desperate life. Not enough room.  90 91 92 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 65.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rob and Jimmy squeeze out onto the wing. Followed by others. The center cannot hold.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: (overwhelmed) Jimmy. Jeff’s still in the plane. Rob makes a sudden move, heads back toward the plane. He tries to step over escaping passengers, but the wing is icy, the water too close, everyone coming towards him in waves. Jimmy finally gets a good grip and Rob fights against it.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: We're not... leaving him in there!

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Crew will grab him, Robbie. Rob sees there is no way back for him. But he can’t accept it. His heart hammers with the darkest of fears. Other passengers cry out. Fear passing between them. Hypothermia climbing from toes to torso like a virus. And every new passenger on the wing... makes the plane -- SINK DEEPER into the river. Which will it be first? Drowning or freezing to death?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CBS reporter RANDALL PINKSTON is live from the docks as the rescue unfolds.

dialogues.speaker: PINKSTON
dialogues.text: With a water temperature of 36 degrees and wind chill of -5, the surviving passengers of Flight 1549 literally... have minutes to live.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY LEONARD 92
dialogues.text: ..-. he has swam 30 yards toward New Jersey. Stops, breathless. Knows he will never make it. Both the coast and the wreckage seem too far a swim. The water owns him.  93 94 95 96 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 66.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donna Dent is shouting/waving to the last remaining MALE PASSENGERS for assistance. And one of them makes it back to the 17th row. And scoops up -- Lucille Palmer into his arms. Diane trails behind as they all make their way to the exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They reach the exit and Lucille is carried with the greatest of care into one of the life rafts. All make room for her and Diane slides in beside her. She holds her mother as if she were a tiny child.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE HIGGINS
dialogues.text: I won’t leave you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gaggero is barking commands to the commuters, mobilizing them to assist in the rescue. And they are responding. United.

dialogues.speaker: GAGGERO
dialogues.text: Oxygen’s in the medical closet! Blankets, aft storage. Life vests in the lockers. Gonna need everybody! (to ship) Come on, you sonofabitch, go! He hits the chop head on. 20 knots, the ferry maxed out, knocked sideways. Ferry passengers hang on like pirates in pursuit, the whole of them ready to help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHAE CHILDERS, 38, frightened, exits onto the wing. She looks to the closest LIFE RAFT. But it is overturned and sinking. She sees a slick of jet fuel in the river... panics... DIVES in, swimming, gulping, trying to get away from the plane. 93 94 95 96  97 98 99 100 101 102 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 67.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The NYPD AIR/SEA RESCUE HELICOPTER flies toward the Hudson.

dialogues.speaker: ACTION
dialogues.text: The Jefferson is the first to arrive at the scene. Gaggero tosses a ROPE into the right-side wing and the rescue is on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barry Leonard finishing his swim back to the left raft, shivering with shock and confusion. Passengers pull the nearly-dead Barry into the raft. They huddle around him for warmth. Giving up their own clothes to warm him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passengers shout out for Shae to return to the wing, but she has seized up with cold and fatigue. She is barely moving, her head dipping below the water’s surface, water rushing into her gaping mouth. Her seat cushion floats away. Drowning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NY1’s BOBBY CUZA films a report, surrounded by a cavalcade of first responders. Police. Firemen. EMT. Awaiting the survivors.

dialogues.speaker: CUZA
dialogues.text: Whoever has miraculously survived this plummet from the skies into the icy Hudson has about three hundred of New York’s finest ready to help them. The only question remaining is, will it be too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bow of the Moira Smith drifts INTO VIEW and there, just bobbing for life is -- Shae Childers. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: We WIDEN to reveal the stern of the Moira Smith swinging toward the front left raft. It stops just before crushing the raft and its survivors against the sinking plane.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Sully, Skiles and a few remaining male passengers stand abreast of the exit and pass out blankets, life vests, spare coats. Anything to stem the cold and keep people alive. Sully grabs the plane’s emergency location transmitter and hands it to someone in the front left raft. Finally, with nothing left to hand out and every other person on a wing or ina raft... Sully walks down the aisle searching for passengers.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Is anyone else here?! Come forward. Come forward! Water up to his waist, teeth chattering, he wades back of the front of the plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The NYPD AIR/SEA RESCUE HELICOPTER arrives overhead, rippling the water and scanning the entire tableau.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With her all strength gone, Shae somehow reaches out and catches the rope ladder attached to the bow of the ferry. But holding on is all she can do. She sobs. She prays. DECKHANDS shout down at her, encouraging her to climb. But her extremities are frozen. And she cannot move an inch.

dialogues.speaker: SHAE
dialogues.text: The boat... is going to pull me under. I have to let go.

dialogues.speaker: DECKHAND ALFONSO
dialogues.text: No! Hang on, ma’am, I can climb down to you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DECKHAND CARLO ALFONSO, limber and fierce, scampers down the rope ladder, reaches for Shae’s hand. But she won't let go of the rope. Too afraid. Too cold.

dialogues.speaker: SHAE
dialogues.text: I can’t... The ferry drifts closer to the left wing. And the wing gets closer and closer, the tip just missing Shae’s back. JOE HART, a Flight 1549 passenger, leaps off the wing and onto to the rope ladder. He desperately tries to pull her up. But she is paralyzed by fear and cold.

dialogues.speaker: SHAE
dialogues.text: I have to go. Please, let me go. Shae nearly gives up. Lets her arms begin to release the ladder... Until the river around her begins to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHIMMER with the NYPD AIR SEA RESCUE HELICOPTER appearing overhead. Scuba cop MIKE DELANEY, wearing only flippers and mask... LEAPS twenty feet from the chopper and swims madly to Shae.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He arrives just in time. Terrified, Shae fights Delaney, pulls him under for a moment. Until at last, Delaney reigns her in.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: You're all right. I got you. I got you, ma’am. Relax! She spits water from her blue lips.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: My name’s Michael, what’s yours? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHAE
dialogues.text: (shivering unstoppably) Shae... Scuba cop Rodriguez leaps out of the helicopter and swims toward the rescue, as well.

dialogues.speaker: SHAE
dialogues.text: I can’t... get on... that boat.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: Then let’s get you on another boat. We got plenty of boats. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: SHAE
dialogues.text: I jumped... I was afraid the plane was going to explode... I’m so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: No apologies. We got this. You and me.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY 108
dialogues.text: Sully is doing a second and final search for passengers. With water up to his belt, he is standing on the seat of the fourth row from the back. Hypothermia chases after Sully as he searches every row, every seat. The cold plays against his heart, shortens his breath.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Captain, it’s time to go! We've got to get off this plane! Right now!

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: They’re here!

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: I aimed for the Intrepid. Close to the boats. Sully climbs over the seats toward the front. Water rising. At the wing exit, one last look as he straddles the doorway... but then he races back toward the cockpit.  109 110 111 112 113 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 7.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sully grabs the metal AIRCRAFT MAINTENANCE LOGBOOK. He snares his overcoat and takes a final look around. The instrument panel is completely dead. EXT. FRONT LEFT DOOR - SULLY’S POV - CONTINUOUS ACTION 11 As he steps OUT of the left forward entry door. Nearly an entire plane-load of people on the slippery wings. The rest in emergency life rafts. But the river is deathly cold. And -- RISING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sully, last man out, squeezes onto one of the life rafts next to Skiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The deckhands use the Jason’s Cradle to rescue Lucille.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sully is rapidly scanning the wings, rafts, everything, his lips moving in a silent count.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last passengers are being plucked from the rafts, including Barry. Deckhands FRANCO SANTINI, gray-haired, linebacker strong, and BRIAN KELLY, 28, laser focus, cover him in blankets as he reaches the deck.

dialogues.speaker: SANTINI
dialogues.text: We gotta warm him up. Get hima blanket. Fast! Kelly wraps him in a blanket.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: I can’t... this isn’t... He grows increasingly distraught. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 113 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 72.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: It’s okay. You’re good now, sir. Kelly takes off his coat and hat and puts them on Barry, to still his quivering, but he can’t stop shaking.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Safe home.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: It was supposed to be me... it was supposed to be me... it was...

dialogues.speaker: SANTINI
dialogues.text: Calm down, sir.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: I was sure I was going to die. Santini embraces Barry, pulls him close. Looks him in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: SANTINI
dialogues.text: Hey. No one dies today.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: who is still counting. Scanning the boats, the rafts, as the final passengers from this raft climb up to safety. He relieves Skiles of the rope connecting them to the Athena ferry, sends him up the ladder. Sully is alone in the raft, trying to hold it close to the ferry, but his frozen hands refuse to function. He's drifting away from the rescuers’ reach.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: (from the ferry) Sully! Wrap it around your arms! Sully barely manages to twist the rope around his frozen arms and pull himself slowly back toward the ferry.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Climb out now! Sully reaches toward the ferry ladder. Has to -- HOOK HIS ELBOWS around the rungs and, rung-by-rung, haul himself up toward the ferry deck. The last three rungs he’s -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: PULLED UP by deckhands and Skiles. They immediately try to throw a blanket around him, but he pushes through. Still carrying the metal aircraft maintenance logbook. While others celebrate and weep, Sully soldiers on, pinpoint focus. Still counting. But he’s so surrounded by “thank you”s and embraces he can’t keep track.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: .-. he goes to a railing, trying to count passengers on the other ferries, even as they dock further down the pier. Impossible. Looks out at the plane, listing and sinking. Then in front of him, on the river... PERSONAL ITEMS begin floating by. Purses, souvenirs, I LOVE NEW YORK bags. The two SNOW GLOBES OF NYC Lucille bought, bobbing in the choppy water. The Statue of Liberty ringed in fake snow, floating on the darkening river. Sully reaches onto his belt for his cell phone. And somehow it works. He dials Lorrie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lorrie casually picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: I wanted to call to say I’m okay.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: Are you still on the 5:50 PM home?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: Oh, Sully. Don’t be late, the girls were really hoping to... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: There’s been an incident. I’m okay. Not a scratch. Somehow. Turn on the television.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: What do you mean, the television? Sully gets swarmed by more grateful embraces.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Lorrie, I can’t talk now. I’11 call you from the pier, once things quiet down.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: Sully. I don’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: I had to land... in the Hudson. I love you. I’m okay, tell the girls I’m okay, but I have to go. Sully hangs up. Lorrie quickly turns on the news, still confused. It’s on every channel that she rifles through. The floating plane. The rescue. It finally begins to dawn on her. And she begins to shake.

dialogues.speaker: TELEVISION
dialogues.text: ZOOM INTO CNN coverage of the rescue, live. The Thomas Jefferson ferry is just pulling into dock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Thomas Jefferson ferry docks to MAYHEM. PRESS everywhere. POLICE trying to keep order amidst the madness. Passengers borrow cell phones from police and firemen to contact love ones immediately. Donna and Sheila continue to help passengers with blankets, comfort, attention. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 115 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 75.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rob Kolodjay disembarks from the ferry and immediately pushes through the crowds. He is wrapped in a blanket and followed by Jimmy, but all he wants to do is find his son, Jeff.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Maybe he’s here, maybe he beat us somehow. There were a lot of boats... (yells out) Jeff! Stops to describe Jeff to police officers. And the swirl of humanity just makes it more exasperating.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: who is just shouldering past, towards... U.S. AIRWAYS Captain DAN BRITT, 54, in full uniform, the union rep from LaGuardia, wearing his union badge. Dan is slender, handsome, easygoing even in this startling environment.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Dan. Need to know who’s hurt and how badly. And I need a count. 155 is my number, passengers and crew.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: How about you?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: I’ll answer that when we’ve counted 155.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: pacing through the thicket of rescuers and rescued, he is handed a phone and begins to dial.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRI LEONARD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I know. You’re calling to say they canceled your flight...

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Sort of. I won’t be home tonight...

dialogues.speaker: SHERRI LEONARD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I knew it. The weather report was bad news. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 76.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Sherri... I can’t believe I’m talking to you.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRI LEONARD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Barry, what is it? You sound...

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: When you were so sick last year, and I asked God that you would be saved and I would be taken instead...

dialogues.speaker: SHERRI LEONARD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What are you... I don’t understand?

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: And you said... God was too merciful to make me hold up my end of the bargain... After a beat.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: «+. you were right.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SULLY
dialogues.text: as a POLICE CAPTAIN sidles up.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Captain, I’m here to escort you to meet with Mayor Bloomberg and Police Commissioner Raymond Kelly.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: If the Mayor wants to say hello, he’1l have to come down here. We're still working.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Sul, I can keep assembling a count. Skiles approaches.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: I need a count, Jeff. I needa count.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: No way to get a real count out here. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 77.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Jeff's right. Let’s get you in some dry clothes before you freeze to death.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Captain, what if the Mayor and Chief Kelly head down here to meet you? It doesn’t change Sully’s point of focus.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: (to Dan Britt) Dan, being a domestic flight...

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: ++. no manifest. We’1ll have to track the passenger info down one- by-one.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Can you get help?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I’ll call John Carey. We’1l get your count. You’ve done enough, Sully. Let me take it from here. Sully sees the flashing lights of the waiting ambulance. But he’s not ready yet. Something draws him to the edge of the pier and Skiles follows. The magnet is the -- PLANE, now lashed to fireboats and ferries. CAMERA FINDS CLOSEUP after CLOSEUP. SULLY AND SKILES. Shock and disbelief. BARRY LEONARD. Tears of joy. DONNA DENT. Silent awe. DIANE and LUCILLE. Exhausted and seeking aid. PASSENGER WITH BABY and 8-MONTH-OLD BABY. Joyous. ROB KOLODJAY, his face cratered by worry and fear... looking at every face that passes, desperate to see his son... Until his cell phone rings. Caller ID reads -- “JEFF”. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rob answers. Hears his son’s voice. All he can do is weep.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I’m okay. Pop. I was on the other wing. And they brought us to Jersey.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: I couldn't find you, I couldn’t see you.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (amped) I heard you shouting my name the whole time. I shouted back. I guess the river...

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: You're okay? You’re not hurt?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I’m okay, Pop. I’m here. Dad. Don’t cry.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I love you, too. Can you believe we made it!? I mean... the plane... crashed. In the river. Are you fucking kidding me!?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, we CIRCLE BACK TO -- Sully and Skiles. Sully is still total concentration. But Skiles finally lets his relief show.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Never been so happy to be in New York in my life.  118 119 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 79.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick, the ATC guy in charge of 1549, sits in this windowless room, head in his hands. He looks like he’s had the longest hour of his life. Tears still pool in his eyes. The door opens and a ATC #1 pops his head in.

dialogues.speaker: ATC
dialogues.text: Hey, Patty, aren’t you coming? Down the hall, noises emanate.

dialogues.speaker: ATC
dialogues.text: Everyone’s going nuts up top. Supe sent me looking for you.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I guess you didn’t hear. Lost Cactus 1549. In the Hudson.

dialogues.speaker: ATC
dialogues.text: I guess you didn’t hear. He landed the sonofabitch.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ATC
dialogues.text: Everyone just got pulled off. It’s a miracle. Patrick grabs his friend in an embrace of disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I thought I lost them all. Man, still being hugged, scans the barren room.

dialogues.speaker: ATC
dialogues.text: They have got to get a TV in here. INT. ST. LUKE’S HOSPITAL - EXTREME CLOSEUP - SULLY’S EYES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A light beam examines cornea and iris. PULL BACK to reveal Sully, still in his wet clothes, sitting on an examination bed. The DOCTOR, 36, thin hair, thinner waist, writes notes on his pad, then listens to Sully’s heart and lungs. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 119 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 80.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: What’s my pulse?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: My normal resting is 55. 110 is not good.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: You're right. It’s not good. After what you just went through, 110 is extraordinary.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: How is Doreen?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Fairly deep laceration, we'll keep her a day or two to stem infection.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: But she’ll...

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: ... have a scar and a story to tell, although no one will believe her. I’m here with you and I don’t believe it. You landed a plane on the Hudson. Not a scratch on you. Rest of your crew, too. A voice from the other side of the curtain.

dialogues.speaker: ARNIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Captain Arnie Gentile to see Captain Sullenberger.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Wow, the union is sending all the big guns today. The curtain pulls back. ARNIE, middle-aged, stocky. Serious.

dialogues.speaker: ARNIE
dialogues.text: I talked to Dan Britt, Sully. We've got a count. A beat. Sully’s heart constricts. (CONTINUED)

For the very first time, Sully’s professional face gives way to something more vulnerable. The shock of the human experience breaks across his brow, shadows his eyes, opens his mouth. He leans against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: ARNIE
dialogues.text: It’s official. 155.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: (spent) 155.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ESTABLISHING of the nondescript hotel. If not for the three police SUVs parked out front, it’d look like just another quiet night in Queens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: U.S. AIR Captain CARL CLARKE, tall, soft-spoken, 50, is walking down the hall with two big shopping bags. He's accompanied by hotel manager EVELYN MAY, late 30s, tall, lovely. They knock on rooms 311 and 313. Skiles exits one door, Sully the other. Skiles is showered and in a robe. Sully is still in his wet uniform, six hours after the landing.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Hey. Carl.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Jeff. Sully. Helluva thing you pulled off out there today.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: We're here. That’s about all I know at the moment. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 82.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: This is Ms. May, from the hotel. She wanted to have a quick word.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: I won't take your time, gentlemen. This is only to say that my staff and I are committed to protecting your privacy. And if there’s anything I can do at all...

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Is it possible... I'd love to get my uniform dry-cleaned overnight. It’s the only clothing I have.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Dry cleaning?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: If it’s too much, this late...

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? Captain Sullenberger, I'd give you this whole hotel if I could. Tears rim her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: The families of crash victims often stay here after... this hotel has seen a lot of grief. But this time... we get to see joy. She hugs him. Sully is stiff, unsure of what to do. Still in shock.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Thanks, Evelyn.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Anything for Sully. Have a blessed day. She walks away, radioing for a bellman to go to Sully’s room.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: What just happened?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: You got hugged by a total stranger. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CARL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) Sully, when’s the last time you heard of someone landing a jet on the water. And everybody lived? Sully is silent.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Exactly. INT. SULLY’S ROOM - MOMENTS LATER 122 Carl empties one bag on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Shaving cream, razors, toothpaste... also got you new clothes. He pulls out identical BLACK SWEATSUITS, socks, and black, low-rise briefs.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: You thought we were ninjas?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: K-Mart was the only store open. It’s Queens at ten in the evening. You find a Brooks Brothers.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: (to Sully) What are you even still doing in uniform?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: I... don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Been a long day. Get some rest. Mike Cleary will be by in the A.M. Make sure you're both doing okay.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Thanks, Carl.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Thank you, Captain. Been awhile since New York had news this good. Especially with an airplane in it. They shake. Take in the gravity of the statement. Then part. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sully stands alone. Uniform wet. Bed full of new items. His phone battery dead. He pulls his wallet out of his soaked trousers. Opens it. The contents are soggy, but intact. Out of an inside slot, he pulls a yellowed slip of paper from a fortune cookie. One he’s carried around for years. Now, he can only look at it in stunned wonder. It reads: “A delay is better than a disaster.” Sully turns on the TV. And every channel is showing -- The plane floating in the Hudson, passengers on the wings. PUSH INTO the TV image, ‘til it pixelates.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The word that city officials keep repeating is ‘timing.’

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULL OUT of TV image until we see we’re back in the bar where Sully was given his “Sully” drink. Reporter is now on-screen.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The perfect timing of the NYPD scuba unit, and the ferry boat captains. And, of course, the inexplicably precise timing of the pilot, Captain Sully Sullenberger, who with almost no time, became a man for all time.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: (to himself) No time. No time... Slowly something seems to be dawning on him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THE BARTENDER
dialogues.text: mixing another drink.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Can I buy you another ‘Sully,’ Sully? But when he turns, Sully is gone and there’s a 20-dollar tip on the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sully’s on the move and he’s on his cell phone. It’s ringing. And ringing.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Answer. Answer.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hel... hello.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: The CVR recording is in two days, how fast can you arrange a favor?

dialogues.speaker: WITH
dialogues.text: INT. LARRY ROONEY’S BEDROOM - SAME TIME 125 Larry Rooney is up on one elbow, half-asleep. His wife, with eyeshades, sleeps next to him.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY ROONEY
dialogues.text: Sully?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: I know Airbus has scheduled simulations in their S22 sim at the factory. Can you get them to reschedule?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY ROONEY
dialogues.text: It’s 1:30 in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sully stops on the corner, the Intrepid moonlit behind him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 86.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: They’re using mostly U.S. Air pilots, some of whom I know, so I got wind of it. Next week in Toulouse.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY ROONEY
dialogues.text: Okay. Yes. That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: I need you to make it happen... before we listen to the CVR. Before our testimony is complete.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY ROONEY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: I have the right to see the simulations. And I have a feeling that with human pilots, not a computer, the results are going to be different.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY ROONEY
dialogues.text: What if they show the exact same result?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: If they do, I’1l hand you my wings myself. It’s all about time, Larry. You can do anything, if you’re never in a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY ROONEY
dialogues.text: I sure as hell agree with that.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: I spent so much time thinking I might have gotten it wrong... I forgot that I had actually gotten it right. (beat) The CVR is on Wednesday. That’s 36 hours. Can you arrange it?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY ROONEY
dialogues.text: I’ll try. That’s a lot of phone calls to make.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: It's already 7:30 in France. You better start now. Sully hangs up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 127A
dialogues.text: 128 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 87.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: And for the first time since the crash, hope in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: EXT. L’ENFANT PLAZA - NTSB HEADQUARTERS - TWO DAYS LATER It’s so cold, even the building looks like it wants to duck for cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door to the NTSB conference room is closed, the noise of set up audible slightly through the door.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: He is about to enter the rest of his life, and gathers himself for what awaits him. His heartbeat has still not slowed since the crash, and even the deepest of breaths cannot slow it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sully enters. Sits next to Skiles. They wait in silence. Larry Rooney sits steadfast, as well as other airline and union reps. Across from them are Porter and the other NTSB board members. All have headsets on the tables in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES PORTER
dialogues.text: Before we listen to the cockpit voice recording, and we will be listening to it for the first time, along with you, gentlemen...

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH DAVIS
dialogues.text: «+. per the request of Captain Sullenberger, and the union, Airbus has agreed to link us via satellite to today’s piloted simulations.

dialogues.speaker: BEN EDWARDS
dialogues.text: Upload the link, please. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sully sits stone-faced. The satellite link revs up and shows the stunning --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The outside looks exactly like the nose of an A320, and it is on a gimbal, to provide the full rise and fall, shaking and plummeting of a distressed plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside it looks exactly like the A320 cockpit. A square-jawed AIRBUS TEST PILOT, 35, in civilian clothing, buckles into the seat with a CO-PILOT beside him. And the flight begins. From inside the cockpit, the simulator shows a perfect graphic representation of the take-off from LaGuardia. Everything is precise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skiles leans toward Sully.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: They're just simulations, Sully. Won't change my mind about what happened up there.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: It might change theirs.

dialogues.speaker: BIRD STRIKE.
dialogues.text: The AUTOMATED WARNING SYSTEM begins inside the “cockpit” and it is devastating and rattling. Even though it’s only a simulator, the Pilot and Co- Pilot’s faces betray the terror of the situation. The simulator drops the plane two stories a second. Death- defying. Then the Pilot makes an IMMEDIATE left turn to return to LaGuardia. Co-Pilot runs the QRH, every proper part of the checklist. Pilot steadies the plane. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Flaps 2, just like Sully used. Everything exactly the same. The approach is harrowing. They can only configure for landing in the last fifteen seconds. Moments from crashing until a -- PERFECT LANDING on LaGuardia runway 1-3. Pilot and Co- Pilot hi-five, like Top Gun devotees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is buzzing after the successful landing.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES PORTER
dialogues.text: For the record, the pilot’s and the computer sims bear the same result. Sully’s expression betrays nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A NEW PILOT, a woman, and NEW CO-PILOT enter the simulator. Take off. Bird strike. Tremors. Chaos of the warning system every 5.7 seconds. The checklist. Attempt for Teterboro. The tension is just as thick. Full concentration. Last minute flaps and another -- Perfect landing on LaGuardia 1-3.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edwards and Porter are writing notes. And the room feels more and more like a gallows. Larry Rooney leans forward toward Sully to say something, but Sully blocks the comment with a gesture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THIRD TEST PILOT, a lanky 40-year-old man, slides into place confidently, with his Co-Pilot. A new target is chosen. Teterboro airport. Bird strike. CHAOS. The river beckoning, and 3rd Pilot yanks the plane into an extreme bank. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The simulator strains at the effort. Extraordinary flying. At the last possible second, he comes out of the bank and -- SLAMS it down on the runway. Harrowing. But safe and sound.

dialogues.speaker: BEN EDWARDS
dialogues.text: Three simulations, multiple runways and airports. Three successful landings. We’re simply mimicking what the computer already told us.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES PORTER
dialogues.text: A lot of toes were stepped on... in order to set this up for today. And, frankly, I’m not sure what you gentlemen planned to gain by it. Silence. The room tightening at the edges.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES PORTER
dialogues.text: Captain Sullenberger? For a moment, it seems Sully is out of rope. Finally...

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Can we get serious now?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES PORTER
dialogues.text: Captain?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: We’ve heard about the computer simulations and now we’re watching actual sims, and I find it hard to believe you're still not taking into account the human factor.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES PORTER
dialogues.text: Human-piloted simulations show that you could have made it back to the airport.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: No. They don’t. His “no” is clear and strong and galvanizes the room’s full attention. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 91.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: These pilots are not reacting like human beings. Like people who are experiencing this for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES PORTER
dialogues.text: They may not be reacting like you did, but...

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Immediately after the bird strike, they’re turning for the airport. Just as in the computer sims, correct?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES PORTER
dialogues.text: That is correct.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: They obviously knew the turn and exactly what heading to fly. They didn’t run a check or switch on the APU...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES PORTER
dialogues.text: They had the same parameters you faced...

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: No one warned us. No one said, you're about to lose both engines... at a lower altitude than any jet in history. But be cool. Turn back for LaGuardia like you're going out to pick up the goddamn milk. His outrage pins the room to the wall.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: This was dual engine loss at 2,800 feet followed by an immediate water landing. With 155 souls on board. No one has ever even trained for an incident like that. No one.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Sully’s right. It’s absurd to expect an immediate turn for the airport. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 92.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: And the Teterboro landing, with the unrealistic bank angle... this wasn’t the Blue Angels up there. I'd like to know how many times the pilot practiced that maneuver before he actually pulled it off. Long pause. No answer from the NTSB forthcoming.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: I’m not questioning the pilots. They’re good pilots. But they’ve clearly been instructed to head to the airports immediately after the bird strike. You have allowed no time for analysis and decision making. And with these sims, you have taken all the humanity out of the cockpit. How much time did these pilots spend making their plans for this event? Hours, days? (beat) You’re looking for human error...? Then make it human. NTSB confers.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: It wasn’t a video game, it was life and death. Sully’s right. That’s worth a few seconds. Charles Porter contacts Airbus via satellite and confers with them while the others await the decision. The room is heavy with anticipation.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Please ask them how many practice runs they had...

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH DAVIS
dialogues.text: The pilot who landed at Teterboro had 17 practice attempts. Before the simulation we just witnessed. All Sully can do is shake his head. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Charles Porter hangs up with Airbus.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES PORTER
dialogues.text: The reaction-decision time will be set at thirty-five seconds.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: (to Sully; sotto) That’s not enough time.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: It’s something. We only had 208 seconds total, so I'll take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first Pilot and his Co-Pilot, who high-fived after their first run, re-enter the simulator. They fly this simulation with more confidence, barely reacting to the bird strike, no fear in their faces. Then they wait 35 seconds before returning to the airport. When they do, they -- CRASH. Coming up short, despite going full aft on the stick. The plane -- CARTWHEELS into the water just short of the runway. And is torn into pieces. The Pilot looks stunned.

dialogues.speaker: PILOT
dialogues.text: Let me run it again. Runway 2-2, with a right turn, is the better choice. Same Pilot. Same 35-second reaction-decision time. This attempt, a hard right turn to LaGuardia, almost like flying blind during the turn. This approach, the -- CRASH is worse. The plane nosedives, half into the water, half onto the edge of the runway. Splinters like a shattered bone.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES PORTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (stoic) Let’s... try Teterboro. The Pilot who successfully landed at Teterboro with the extreme 66 degree bank and sudden set down, buckles in. The flight. The madness of noise and technology. The delay and turn for Teterboro. The plane banked hard to 66 degrees, just as before, but this time the plane doesn’t make it to Teterboro. It -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: STRIKES several buildings on the Jersey side of the river and DISINTEGRATES onscreen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sully isn’t smiling on the outside. But on the inside... The 35-second delay, the human delay, is making all the difference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Attempt after attempt, for Teterboro or LaGuardia. With the 35-second delay -- Crash after crash. Finally --

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Does anyone need to see any more simulations? This time, the NTSB is silent. Skiles can’t hide his grin.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Now that we've seen what could have happened... can we listen to what actually did? It takes a beat, but Charles Porter finally shuts down the satellite link.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES PORTER
dialogues.text: We’ll study all the results at a later date. Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH DAVIS
dialogues.text: For the record, this is the CVR of U.S. Airways Flight 1549, January 15th, 2009. (beat) Gentlemen, headsets. They all don their headsets. And the switch is flipped. Sully and Skiles close their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: The sky is achingly blue. It’s 3:27 PM on a Thursday afternoon. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A flock of CANADIAN GEESE appear, thick as a black and gray curtain, in an exact Y-pattern. The sound of their wings is rhythmic. Peaceful. Perfect.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Birds! They are 100 yards away when Sully sees them. Before he blinks, they shadow the windscreen completely.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Whoa! Several birds enter each engine. The engines both shudder to a complete and silent stop. Then BURST INTO FLAMES.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Oh, shit.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Uh, oh...

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: We got one rol... both of ‘em rolling back. The power drains from the plane like blood from an open vein.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: I’m starting the APU. Sully flips on the auxiliary power unit. No engines, but now enough power to buy them a little time. A very little.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: (beat) My aircraft.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Your aircraft. Sully’s focus is absolute. And his bearing, calm, but inside, his heart thunders. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Get the QRH. Loss of thrust on both engines. Skiles grabs the Quick Reference Handbook. It has 150 checklists for various emergencies. Which one works for double engine loss at 2,800 feet? None of them. Down below, the Hudson rushes up at them like an attack. Sully turns left and calls ATC.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Mayday, Mayday, Mayday, this is Cactus 1549, hit birds, we've lost thrust on both engines. We’re turning back towards LaGuardia. INT. ATC —- CONTINUOUS ACTION 142 Sully’s called “Mayday,” but Patrick, the ATC, hasn’t heard it. He has keyed his microphone and is talking to another departing aircraft in his charge, oblivious to the danger. Patrick releases his mic, sips his coffee in time to finally hear.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: «+. we’ve lost thrust on both engines. We’re turning back toward LaGuardia. Patrick sits up straight at the news. Immediately, charts a return route on his computer.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Okay, you need to return to LaGuardia. (beat) Turn left, heading of two-two- zero.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Two-two-zero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skiles reads from the QRH. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 97.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: ‘If fuel remaining, engine mode selector, ignition. Ignition.’

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Ignition.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: ‘Thrust levers confirm idle.’

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Idle.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: ‘Airspeed optimum relight, three hundred knots.’ Skiles looks at the instrument board.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: We don’t have that.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: We don’t.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Tower, stop your departures, we got an emergency returning. 1549. Bird strike. He lost both engines. Returning immediately. LaGUARDIA TOWER (V.O.) Which engine?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: He lost thrust in both engines. He said. Patrick’s face pales. “Both engines” begins to sink in.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Cactus 1549, if we can get it for you, do you want to try to land runway one-three? The alarm chimes punctuate Patrick’s transmission. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sully looks out of the window. The Hudson is below. Sully’s mind calculates how long he has remaining. He sees the -- Manhattan skyline to the left. New Jersey to the right, the riverfront thick with buildings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PEOPLE watching TV, in their waterfront apartments, oblivious that their lives are at risk. A SIX-YEAR-OLD LITTLE GIRL with a dog, coming to the window at the sound of the jet plane. An ELDERLY MAN, with a cane, at his window, watching it all. Every building buzzing with life, just one bad decision away from death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It takes Sully only a few seconds to realize he’s out of choices.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: We're unable. We may end up in the Hudson. Skiles continues the checklist.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: ‘Emergency electrical power. Emergency generator not online.’

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: It’s online.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: ‘ATC notify. Squawk seventy-seven hundred. Distress message transmit.’ We did.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Cactus 1549, it’s gonna be left traffic for runway three-one.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Unable. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 99.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Okay. What do you need to land?

dialogues.speaker: WARNING SYSTEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ‘Go around. Wind shear ahead.’

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: ‘FAC one off, then on.’ Sully watches the altimeter plummet. Looks left and right. And now, this low, only 1200 feet above the Hudson, water is all he sees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick checks his time readout.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (to himself) Been ten seconds, Captain. Come on. Talk to me. (into radio) Cactus 1549, runway four’s available if you wanna make left traffic to runway four.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I’m not sure we can make any runway.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Uh, what’s over to our right, anything in New Jersey? Maybe Teterboro? Skiles pauses a mini-beat. His first doubt. Almost challenges Sully, bites down on it.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (relieved) Okay, yeah, off your right side is Teterboro airport. Patrick works his touchscreen like a magician. Gets the number he needs and dials. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: LaGuardia departure, got an emergency inbound.

dialogues.speaker: TETERBORO TOWER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is Teterboro Tower, go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Cactus 1549 over the GW bridge, wants to go to the airport right now.

dialogues.speaker: TETERBORO TOWER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Check, does he need assistance?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Yes. Bird strike. Can I get him in for runway one.

dialogues.speaker: TETERBORO TOWER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Runway one. That’s good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane is dropping like a stone. The bridge looks like it’s going to clip a wing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skiles looks to Sully. Sees his calm. But wants to contradict the Teterboro call. Waits. Every second an eternity.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: ‘No relight after thirty seconds, engine master one and two confirm off.’ SULLY’S POV as they just -- BARELY clear the GW bridge. And its massive traffic. Already, lives saved.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You wanna try and go to Teterboro? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: off.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: ‘Wait thirty seconds.’ Sully hears “thirty seconds.” Knows he doesn’t have it. Reaches for the radio to the cabin.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: (into PA) This is the Captain. (pause) Brace for impact.

dialogues.speaker: AUTOMATED VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ‘One thousand...’

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: (excited) Cactus 1549, turn right, two-eight zero. You can land runway one at Teterboro.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We can’t do it.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Okay. Which runway would you like at Teterboro?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: (to Skiles) Go ahead. Try number one. Nothing from the engine.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: (into radio) We’re gonna be in the Hudson. Sully slips his shoulder harness belt back into place and secures it.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, say again, Cactus 1549. Sully doesn’t key the radio. His only focus now, landing the plane on the roiling river. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WARNING SYSTEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ‘Too low. Too low. Terrain. Terrain.’ The chimes are relentless. Cockpit noise, cacophonous. Sully eyes the approaching water as if it were a runway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost all are leaning forward, braced for impact, as the flight attendants keep reciting, over and over...

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: Brace, brace! Heads down, stay down! Barry Leonard prays. Diane holds her mother Lucille’s hand. Jeff Kolodjay cannot bear to look out the window as the enormous river seems to rise to meet them.

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ATTENDANTS
dialogues.text: (shout ) Brace! -- one more time, then bow their heads and lean forward. Only sounds remaining are... A prayer in Russian... the words need no translation. The sound of a text being rush-typed. TEXT: I love you and the girls. The word “delivered” on the screen, bringing deep relief. Message sent/message received. An overlapping chorus of praise and fear and hope and goodbye... Some on their cell phones... “Daddy loves you, you know that, Jesse? Daddy loves you forever...” Some from their souls... “Thank you... for this life.” “Please. God. Mercy. Please.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chimes. Alarms. Automated warnings. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 103.

dialogues.speaker: WARNING SYSTEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ‘Too low. Terrain. Terrain.’

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: No relight.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Okay. Let’s go put the flaps out, put the flaps out.

dialogues.speaker: WARNING SYSTEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ‘Caution. Terrain. Caution.’

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Flaps out?

dialogues.speaker: WARNING SYSTEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ‘Terrain. Pull up. Pull up.’

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Cactus 1549, radar contact lost. You also got Newark off your two o'clock in about seven miles.

dialogues.speaker: WARNING SYSTEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ‘Pull up, pull up, pull up, pull up.’

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Got flaps out. Two hundred fifty feet in the air.

dialogues.speaker: WARNING SYSTEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ‘Too low. Terrain. Too low. Gear.’

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Hundred and seventy knots. Got no power on either one? Try the other one.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Try the other one.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Cactus 1549. You still on?

dialogues.speaker: WARNING SYSTEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ‘Caution. Terrain.’

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Cactus 1549, you got runway two- nine available at Newark, it’1ll be two o’clock and seven miles. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Hundred and fifty knots. Got flaps two. You want more?

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: No, let’s stay at two. (beat) Got any ideas?

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Actually, not.

dialogues.speaker: WARNING SYSTEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ‘Terrain, terrain, pull up, pull up, pull up.’ Sully eyeballs the landing. Eyes on the airspeed displays, then the water. Back and forth. Outside. Inside. Outside. Inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sully fights to keep the plane’s pitch optimum, the nose up. The wings level. One inch off and the plane will disintegrate on impact.

dialogues.speaker: WARNING SYSTEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ‘Pull up, pull up, pull up.’

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the dark water, only feet from impact, RACING to meet us. The plane’s skin shivers and moans. No escape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sully begins the flare for landing. Sidestick back, back, full aft, everything he’s got.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: We’re gonna brace. 104. 156 157 158 159

dialogues.speaker: UP
dialogues.text: 160 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WARNING SYSTEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ‘Pull up, pull up, pull up, pull up.’

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SLAM. The plane hits the Hudson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Underwater. Blackness. All the power gone. Panel completely dark. Dead. Finally, the nose begins to bob up, and as the water clears, Sully and Skiles have a sudden and perfect view of the -- MANHATTAN SKYLINE. Dream-like. As if they’re inside a snow globe, all of NY, opening before them at river level. Sully and Skiles look at each other. Alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. No more words. Who could have survived that? The recording is over. The room hums with the quiet of shock. For the first time, Porter and the other board members seem to really look at Sully and Skiles. To take them in. To realize that they survived this impossibility. This was a miracle on the Hudson. Sully and Skiles betray almost no emotion, still shaken.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: (rising) I need a quick break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sully and Skiles walk side-by-side, not a word between them.  165 166 167 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 106. INT. BATHROOM —- CONTINUOUS ACTION 165 Sully and Skiles wash their hands. Still mute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sully exits alone, and as he waits for Skiles, his phone rings. Lorrie.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Lorrie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lorrie is lying on their bed. Next to her is a large, opened FEDEX PACKAGE which held... SULLY’S SUITCASE, rescued from the wreckage of Flight 1549. Including his -- Pilot’s hat. Which Lorrie is cradling in her hands. Tears steal the rest of her speech.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: Sweetheart, what happened?

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: For the first time, just now, I realized that there were 155 people on that plane. And you were one of them. More tears. Tears of relief and joy.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: I almost lost you. The girls almost lost you.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: But you didn’t. I’m here. Long pause as they simply take in the sound of each other’s breathing. Their existence. It is beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: How are you holding up? Tell me it’s almost over.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: It’s almost over. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LORRIE
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: I love you. Sully hangs up. Takes a moment to gather himself. Skiles exits the bathroom and joins Sully as they walk in silence back toward the conference room. Just before they reach the doors... Sully stops. Skiles stops, too. Faces Sully.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: What did you think? Listening to the CVR. Now. Skiles can’t muster an answer.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: I‘11 tell you what I think... I’m just so damn proud of you. You were right there with me, through all those distractions. With so much at stake. (pause) We did this together. We were a team. Skiles’ eyes brim with tears.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Thank you. Then they lock into an embrace. Brothers. For life. When they step back, the emotion is an invisible cord between them.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: We did our job.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: We did our job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All have returned. The weight of the investigation has been replaced by a sense of humble awe. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 168 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 108.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES PORTER
dialogues.text: That is, honestly, the first time I have listened to a crash recording... while actually sitting with the Captain and First Officer. Extraordinary.

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: That was no simulation.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES PORTER
dialogues.text: No, it wasn’t. The NTSB board is looking for the right words. Finally...

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH DAVIS
dialogues.text: I also wanted to let you know that the left engine was recovered late yesterday. Sully waits a beat. The monitors they have been watching come to life with VIDEO FOOTAGE... A massive crane lifts the LEFT ENGINE from the Hudson River. It dangles over the water, facing away. Its damage unseen. On the video, the LEFT ENGINE rotates TOWARD CAMERA. It is mangled and decimated from within and without.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH DAVIS
dialogues.text: Extensive damage on both the guide vanes and fan blades of the engine. Five compressor blades were fractured and eight variable guide vanes... missing.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: No thrust.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH DAVIS
dialogues.text: As you testified, it was completely destroyed. The ACARS data was wrong. Sully and Skiles are transfixed by the video of the engine that almost got them killed.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH DAVIS
dialogues.text: I'd like to add something on a personal note. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH DAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can say with confidence, that after speaking with the rest of the flight crew, with bird experts and airplane engineers, after running all the scenarios and talking to each of the players... ...there is an X in this result. It’s you, Captain Sullenberger. Take you out of the equation and the math just fails.

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: I disagree. The room hushes. Waiting for Sully to finally unleash. Instead...

dialogues.speaker: SULLY
dialogues.text: It wasn’t just me. It was all of us. Jeff, Donna, Sheila, Doreen. The passengers, the rescue workers. Air traffic control. The ferry boat crews and the scuba cops. We did it. We survived.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH DAVIS
dialogues.text: First Officer Skiles, is there anything you’d like to add? Anything you would have done differently, if you had to do it all again?

dialogues.speaker: SKILES
dialogues.text: Yes. (beat) I would have done it in July. Laughter surprises the room. Finally, a little space to breathe. FADE TO WHITE.

dialogues.speaker: LATER, (REAL-LIFE FOOTAGE)
dialogues.text: The wreckage of U.S. AIR Flight 1549 on full display. The damage to the fuselage, the missing left engine. It doesn’t look like the kind of plane you walk away from alive. The lobby is filling up with visitors, but not just any tourists. Flight 1549 passengers, one and all. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 169 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 110.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The real-life SURVIVORS... They were strangers when they boarded the flight. Now they are family forever. Jeff Skiles enters. An eruption of APPLAUSE, as Sully enters and signals for... Jeff and Donna and Sheila and Doreen to join him. He pulls them in line with him, so that the crew of 1549 are receiving the cheers. As one. FADE OUT.
